com/

The above link is to an interesting site in Japan of the Nihontou 
To=
sougou Kenkyukai.  You can patch the page into the altavista link 
for a 't=
ranslation' although we all know how Japanese to English 
translates by now=
.  On the left side of the page there are a series 
of lectures which have =
many examples to see, both sword and 
fittings.  Lecture three has several =
Ezo examples.

OK Alan, here is a further quote from Buttweiler;

     'The=
 surface of Ezo Menuki were originally covered by a thick 
layer of Gold ap=
plied as an amalgam.  The Gold was burnished with a 
rather large needle wh=
ich left well defined polishing marks.  The 
Gold used for the overlay was =
of very low karat.  The resulting color 
is a very pale Silver-Golden hue. =
 The Gold will frequently be worn 
from the high spots leaving a black Shak=
udo-like patina'.

I have a feeling that much of what we see tody are the r=
emnants of 
field worn gear.  This might explain the relatively poor condit=
ion of 
many of these very early fittings.  Fine pieces for the commanders =
or 
Daimyo were passed on as family treasures or left to shrines.  The 
vas=
t majority of the rest were simply lost to battle or to time.
